BackgroundObjectivesDatasetsReferences


Forests play a vital role in regulating the global carbon cycle, yet their aboveground biomass (AGB) remains difficult to estimate over large areas due to limitations of field-based measurements. Remote sensing offers a scalable solution, but the choice of satellite data remains challenging. This study addresses the challenge by evaluating satellite-based approaches to estimate AGB in Kwahu South, Ghana



Identifying the optimal approach for estimating AGB in Ghana
Evaluating the accuracy AGB estimation models derived from Landsat 9, PlanetSocpe, and 30-m PlanetScope with GEDI L4A serving as a reference data




Landsat 9 imagery (date of the images: 12/2022)
PlanetScope imagery (date of the images: 12/2022)
GEDI L4A data (date of the data: 09/2022 to 02/2023)
Digital Elevation Model (DEM)



Pan, Y., Birdsey, R. A., Fang, J., Houghton, R., Kauppi, P., Kurz, W. A., Phillips, O. L., Shvidenko, A., Lewis, S. L., Canadell, J. G., Ciais, P., Jackson, R. B., Pacala, S. W., McGuire, A. D., Piao, S., Rautiainen, A., Sitch, S., & Hayes, D. (2011). A Large and Persistent Carbon Sink in the World‚Äôs Forests. ResearchGate. https://www.researchgate.net/publication/51498031_A_Large_and_Persistent_Carbon_Sink_in_the_World‚Äôs_Forests
Tian, L., Wu, X., Tao, Y., Li, M., Qian, C., Liao, L., & Fu, W. (2023). Review of Remote Sensing-Based Methods for Forest Aboveground Biomass Estimation: Progress, Challenges, and Prospects. Forests, 14(6), Article 6. https://doi.org/10.3390/f14061086






The study area is located in Kwahu South District, Ghana
Total area: 795.76 km2
Main climate: wet semi equatorial
Forest zone: semi-deciduous







The main approach for developing AGB estimation model in this project is as follow: - Generated a rescaled 30-m PlanetScope imagery

Calculated vegetation indices (NDVI, EVI, NDWI, MSAVI, and GCI) from Landsat 9, PlanetScope, and rescaled 30-m PlanetScope imagery
Computed the aspect from the DEM
Applying random forest algorithm for AGB estimation with input variables were spectral bands, vegetation indices, aspect, and DEM. GEDI L4A was used as groundtruth data for validating each model
Evaluated the accuracy of AGB estimation model derived from Landsat 9, PlanetScope, and rescaled 30-m PlanetScope







Landsat 9 modelPlanetScope modelRescaled 30-m PlanetScope model










Result derived from Image ¬© 2022 Planet Labs PBC





Result derived from Image ¬© 2022 Planet Labs PBC



Though Planet had finer spatial resolution, it still demonstrated a less accurate result compared to Landsat 9. Meanwhile, the rescaled Planet provided the best performance, suggesting that spatial resolution alone did not determine AGB estimation accuracy. One potential explanation for this result is the misalignment between Planet‚Äôs 3m resolution and GEDI‚Äôs 25m footprint.That explains when the PlanetScope was rescaled to 30m, it better matched the scale of GEDI‚Äôs footprint, improving alignment and reducing fine-scale noise.






This map presents a sample of AGB predictions generated using Landsat 9 imagery. Due to licensing restrictions associated with PlanetScope data, maps derived from Planet imagery cannot be shared in this e-portfolio. However, a key takeaway from the comparison is the difference in how AGB is represented, especially in urban areas in the western part of the study region. In the Landsat 9 map, urban zones are less clearly separated from surrounding biomass values. In contrast, the AGB model based on PlanetScope data offers a smoother and more refined spatial distribution, improving the distinction between built-up and vegetated areas. This highlights the potential advantage of rescaling high-resolution data to a coarser resolution to enhance the consistency of AGB estimates by reducing noise while preserving meaningful spatial patterns.




In conclusion, this study evaluated the accuracy of AGB estimation models derived from Landsat 9 and PlanetScope, with GEDI L4A serving as reference. From the results, the most optimal model was identified. The findings demonstrated that finer resolution alone does not guarantee improved model performance. This study also emphasized the importance of matching the spatial scale of input data with reference measurements to enhance the accuracy of biomass prediction.

title: Analysis of Burn Severity and Vegetation Recovery at Prouton Lake, BC
Analysis of Burn Severity and Vegetation Recovery at Prouton Lake, BC
text:
Post-fire vegetation recovery
The yearly NDVI composites from 2018 to 2021 illustrate the temporal pattern of vegetation recovery following the Prouton Lakes Fire. In 2018, NDVI values are relatively low across the burned area, particularly in the central and southern regions, indicating limited photosynthetic activity and sparse vegetation cover shortly after the fire. By 2019, there is a slight increase in NDVI in scattered patches, suggesting the early stages of regrowth. This trend continues in 2020 and becomes more apparent in 2021, where broader areas show higher NDVI values (greener shades), reflecting increasing vegetation density and health. The gradual shift toward green and yellow tones over the four years indicates a progressive recovery of plant cover, although full canopy regeneration has not yet been achieved. These spatial NDVI patterns align with typical successional trajectories seen after wildfire events, where initial colonization by herbaceous species is followed by slower woody vegetation growth.

Prouton Lakes is located in the Cariboo Chilcotin Region of British Columbia, Canada, east of Williams Lake (Kitchen et al., 2022). It is situated near the Alex Fraser Research Forest (AFRF), which serves as a research and education site for sustainable forest management (Kitchen et al., 2022).

The RGB composites show the condition of Prouton Lake and surrounding forest before (July 2015) and after the fire event (July 2018). In the pre-fire image, dense and healthy vegetation is visible as dark green patches, indicating an intact forest canopy. By contrast, the post-fire image reveals extensive areas of white, light brown, and grey, suggesting widespread vegetation loss and exposed soil ‚Äî typical signs of high burn severity. The boundaries of the burn scar are clearly defined, with sharp contrasts between affected and unaffected areas. This transformation is especially evident around the central and northern parts of the scene. While RGB images give a visual sense of change, false-color composites or spectral indices such as NBR or NDVI would provide a more quantitative assessment of vegetation health and burn intensity.

title: Proposal: Evaluating the Impact of Landsacape Fragmentation on Carbon Sequestration of Forests in Kwahu South, Ghana using Landscape Metrics and Landsat 8 Data
text:
Introduction: It is ambiguous that highly fragmented forest enhances carbon sequestration ability.
In recent years, the impact of forest fragmentation on carbon sequestration has become a topic of intense scientific debate (Hou et al., 2024; Ma et al., 2017). The increasing fragmentation of forest landscapes poses a significant threat to their ecosystem service (Fischer et al., 2021). While studies suggest that landscape fragmentation leads to reduced carbon storage capacity due to an increase in edge effects (Fischer et al., 2021), others have reported opposite findings (Lei et al., 2024). A recent study in subtropical forests found that carbon uptake capacity per unit area was enhanced in highly fragmented forest landscape (Jiao et al., 2024). The controversies of carbon uptake capacity between fragmented forest and continuous forest have prompted the need for further research in diverse forest ecosystems.
To address this research gap, my study aims to evaluate the impact of landscape fragmentation on carbon sequestration of forest in Kwahu South, Ghana. Additionally, the impact of landscape fragmentation in the studied area on carbon absorption ability remain poorly understood. In this study, I will use landscape metrics derived from satellite imagery (Landsat 8) and combine them with carbon stock estimates to quantify the relationship between forest fragmentation and carbon sequestration capacity.


Methods
The satellite imagery of Landsat 8 from the United States Geological Survey (USGS) with spatial resolution of 30 meters will be downloaded (EarthExplorer, n.d.). I will perform supervised classification using Random Forest algorithm to create a forest/non-forest map. Using landscape metrics package in RStudio, I will calculate landscape metrics such as Patch Density (PD), Edge Density (ED), Mean Patch Size (MPS), Largest Patch Index (LPI), and Euclidean Nearest Neighbor Distance (ENN). The description for each metric is shown in Table 1. To estimate carbon stocks, I will utilize allometric equations developed by Aabeyir et al.¬†(2020) in combination with field measurements of diameter at breast height and tree height supplied by Ostrom Climate. I will also use the Normalized Difference Vegetation Index (NDVI) derived from Landsat 8 as a proxy for biomass, calibrating it with the field data. Finally, I will use linear regression to quantify the relationship between the calculated metrics and the estimated carbon stocks (Lei et al., 2024). The results allow me to assess how different fragmentation patterns relate to carbon sequestration capacity in the area.


Expected results and significance
I expect a negative correlation between fragmentation metrics (such as Edge Density and Patch Density) and carbon sequestration capacity. Specifically, area with higher edge density will show lower carbon stocks due to increased edge effect. In addition, continuous forest patches (indicated by higher Mean Patch Size and Largest Patch Index) will demonstrate greater carbon sequestration capacity. Similar findings have been observed in research indicating that, in non-commercial forests, fragmentation reduces the carbon storage due to the influence of patch area, edge and patchy connection(Lei et al., 2024). The Figure 1 illustrates the correlation between each fragmentation metric and its corresponding carbon stock.
The results will provide implications such as climate change mitigation. Understanding how fragmentation affects carbon storage can contribute to more accurate estimates of carbon stocks and potential emissions from forest degradation. Another significance from this study is demonstration of carbon sequestration benefits of maintaining large and contiguous forest patches. This insight is particularly significant for guiding conservation strategies and improving land management practices.

Load the necessary library

Preparation of data for analysis
For this study, the LiDAR point cloud data, stored in .las files, had already been normalized. This pre-processing step simplifies subsequent analysis by adjusting the elevation values relative to the ground surface rather than absolute elevation.
Extract the specific plot. The coordinate of the plot is listed in the .csv files.

title: Individual Trees Detecting using different methods
section: Detect individual trees using a point cloud
text:
Detect individual trees using a point cloud
The individual tree detection (ITD) method developed by Li et al.¬†(2012) segments trees directly from LiDAR point cloud data without relying on intermediate raster products like canopy height models. This top-down, region-growing approach begins by identifying the highest point in the cloud, assumed to be a tree top, and sequentially classifies neighboring points based on 2D spatial distance, adaptive spacing thresholds, and tree shape characteristics. By leveraging the 3D structure of the forest, the algorithm effectively distinguishes individual trees even in complex, overlapping canopies.


Code
#segment trees using li2012 algorithm 
segmented_plot_1 <- segment_trees(Lab5_Plot_1, li2012(dt1 = 1.5, 
                                                      dt2 = 2, 
                                                      R = 2, 
                                                      Zu = 15, 
                                                      speed_up = 10, 
                                                      hmin = 2))


Figure 1. ITD using Li et al.¬†2012 method

title: Individual Trees Detecting using different methods
section: Detect individual trees using a CHM
text:
Detect individual trees using a CHM
Dalponte and Coomes (2016) developed a tree-centric approach for individual tree detection (ITD) using canopy height models (CHMs) derived from airborne laser scanning. Their method identifies individual tree crowns by detecting local maxima in the CHM, then applies a region-growing algorithm to delineate tree boundaries based on vertical height differences. Each delineated crown is used to extract tree height and crown area, from which stem diameter and aboveground biomass are estimated using species-specific allometric equations. Hyperspectral imagery aids in tree species classification, enabling more accurate wood density assignment. This CHM-based ITD framework enables high-resolution carbon density mapping, though it is limited in detecting small understory trees hidden beneath the canopy.
Figure 2. ITD using Dalponte and Coomes 2016 method


Code
# Using Dalponte and Coomes 2016 algorithm to detect individual trees
tree_crowns_plot1 <- segment_trees(Lab5_Plot_1, dalponte2016(chm_plot1, 
                                                             tree_tops,
                                                             th_tree = 2,
                                                             th_seed = 0.45,
                                                             th_cr = 0.55,
                                                             max_cr = 10,
                                                             ID = "treeID"))

title: Analysis of Suitable Sanctuaries for Humpback Whales
text:
ArcGIS Pro
Suitability Analysis
Handling Vector Data


BackgroundObjectivesData descriptionsReferences


Hawaii is an archipelago located in the central Pacific Ocean, approximately 3850 km from Californa, USA (World Atlas, n.d). Aside being a wonderful place for visitors, Hawaii archipelago is also home to Humpback Whales during the winter time. The whales swim from Alaska to Hawaii to mate, give birth, and nurture their calves (Hawaii Wildlife Fund, n.d). Recognized as one of the world‚Äôs most vital humpback whale habitats, the Hawaiian Islands Humpback Whale National Marine Sanctuary was established in 1992 to safeguard humpback whales (Megaptera novaeangliae) and their habitat in Hawai‚Äòi (Division of Aquatic Resources, n.d). However, there have been reports about collisions between whales and human activities and objects such as cruise ships, whale watching boats, and fishing boats. Therefore, government agencies are working to identify the most suitable and expansive areas to incorporate into the sanctuary.
In order to complete the tasks, suitability analysis and overlay analysis were performed. Suitability analysis is a process used to determine the suitability of an area for a particular use or purpose based on given weighted criteria (ESRI a, n.d). Overlay analysis is a common method used in suitability analysis, which combines multiple dataset to create a comprehensive assessment (ArcMap, n,d).



The main objectives of this task is to create areas of the 5 most suitable sanctuary for Humpback Whales in Hawaii based on the weighted suitability index.




The data is obtained from UBC-postgres database. The necessary dataset used in this task are whale species, regions in which the whales appear, human activities that affect the whales.



ArcMap. (n.d). Overlay analysis. https://desktop.arcgis.com/en/arcmap/latest/analyze/commonly-used-tools/overlay-analysis.htm
Division of Aquatic Resources. (n.d). Hawaiian Islands Humpback Whale National Marine Sanctuary (HIHWNMS). https://dlnr.hawaii.gov/dar/marine-managed-areas/hawaiian-islands-humpback-whale-national-marine-sanctuary-hihwnms/
ESRI. (n.d). Perform a suitability analysis. https://pro.arcgis.com/en/pro-app/latest/help/analysis/business-analyst/understanding-suitability-analysis.htm
Hawaii Wildlife Fund. (n.d). Humpback Whale. https://www.wildhawaii.org/wildlife/whales/
World Atlas. (n.d). Maps of Hawaii. https://www.worldatlas.com/maps/united-states/hawaii







The interactive map above shows the top 5 suitable sanctuary for the humpback whales. These areas were identified through a suitability analysis based on three key factors: area size, whale sighting frequency, and vessel traffic. The 5 km buffer zones around each sanctuary highlight potential areas of influence, while the most suitable areas within the sanctuaries are emphasized in red. This visualization helps inform decision-making for marine conservation and habitat protection.

The RGB composites show the condition of Prouton Lake and surrounding forest before (July 2015) and after the fire event (July 2018). In the pre-fire image, dense and healthy vegetation is visible as dark green patches, indicating an intact forest canopy. By contrast, the post-fire image reveals extensive areas of white, light brown, and grey, suggesting widespread vegetation loss and exposed soil ‚Äî typical signs of high burn severity. The boundaries of the burn scar are clearly defined, with sharp contrasts between affected and unaffected areas. This transformation is especially evident around the central and northern parts of the scene. While RGB images give a visual sense of change, false-color composites or spectral indices such as NBR or NDVI would provide a more quantitative assessment of vegetation health and burn intensity.

title: Analysis of Burn Severity and Vegetation Recovery at Prouton Lake, BC
text:
NDVI time series
The NDVI time series illustrates notable vegetation dynamics across the Prouton Lakes Fire area between 2013 and 2021. From 2013 to 2016, there is a steady decline in average NDVI, reaching a pronounced low in 2016 ‚Äî likely corresponding with the year of the wildfire event. This sharp dip indicates a significant loss of live green vegetation, consistent with high burn severity. In 2017, NDVI rebounds sharply, suggesting early signs of post-fire vegetation recovery. However, the values remain lower than pre-fire levels and show moderate fluctuations in the following years. The gradual upward trend from 2019 to 2021 may reflect ongoing regrowth and ecological succession, although the NDVI has not yet returned to its original state observed before the fire.

The Malcolm Knapp Research Forest (MKRF) is a 5,157-hectare forest located in Maple Ridge, British Columbia, approximately 60 km from Vancouver (The University of British Columbia, n.d.). title: Analysis of Suitable Sanctuaries for Humpback Whales
text:
ArcGIS Pro
Suitability Analysis
Handling Vector Data


BackgroundObjectivesData descriptionsReferences


Hawaii is an archipelago located in the central Pacific Ocean, approximately 3850 km from Californa, USA (World Atlas, n.d). Aside being a wonderful place for visitors, Hawaii archipelago is also home to Humpback Whales during the winter time. The whales swim from Alaska to Hawaii to mate, give birth, and nurture their calves (Hawaii Wildlife Fund, n.d). Recognized as one of the world‚Äôs most vital humpback whale habitats, the Hawaiian Islands Humpback Whale National Marine Sanctuary was established in 1992 to safeguard humpback whales (Megaptera novaeangliae) and their habitat in Hawai‚Äòi (Division of Aquatic Resources, n.d). However, there have been reports about collisions between whales and human activities and objects such as cruise ships, whale watching boats, and fishing boats. Therefore, government agencies are working to identify the most suitable and expansive areas to incorporate into the sanctuary.
In order to complete the tasks, suitability analysis and overlay analysis were performed. Suitability analysis is a process used to determine the suitability of an area for a particular use or purpose based on given weighted criteria (ESRI a, n.d). Overlay analysis is a common method used in suitability analysis, which combines multiple dataset to create a comprehensive assessment (ArcMap, n,d).



The main objectives of this task is to create areas of the 5 most suitable sanctuary for Humpback Whales in Hawaii based on the weighted suitability index.




The data is obtained from UBC-postgres database. The necessary dataset used in this task are whale species, regions in which the whales appear, human activities that affect the whales.



ArcMap. (n.d). Overlay analysis. https://desktop.arcgis.com/en/arcmap/latest/analyze/commonly-used-tools/overlay-analysis.htm
Division of Aquatic Resources. (n.d). Hawaiian Islands Humpback Whale National Marine Sanctuary (HIHWNMS). https://dlnr.hawaii.gov/dar/marine-managed-areas/hawaiian-islands-humpback-whale-national-marine-sanctuary-hihwnms/
ESRI. (n.d). Perform a suitability analysis. https://pro.arcgis.com/en/pro-app/latest/help/analysis/business-analyst/understanding-suitability-analysis.htm
Hawaii Wildlife Fund. (n.d). Humpback Whale. https://www.wildhawaii.org/wildlife/whales/
World Atlas. (n.d). Maps of Hawaii. https://www.worldatlas.com/maps/united-states/hawaii







The interactive map above shows the top 5 suitable sanctuary for the humpback whales. These areas were identified through a suitability analysis based on three key factors: area size, whale sighting frequency, and vessel traffic. The 5 km buffer zones around each sanctuary highlight potential areas of influence, while the most suitable areas within the sanctuaries are emphasized in red. This visualization helps inform decision-making for marine conservation and habitat protection.
